text: oof

i remember reading about this interaction and doing some digging. this Tomas guy attempted to clarify after her response that he was saying “I read the full article”, rather than making an imperative statement to her: “Read the full article”. not to say there aren’t issues with the response but this snapshot blew up regardless of full context. curious to know if/how that changes the meaning for others
:neutral_face:
even with that context, it speaks volumes that the response would be so common as to seem genuine
that is a good point
even “I read the full article” implies that she didn’t
and he obviously didn’t read her name on the article
maybe twitter isn't the place that we're going to solve this?

i think that’s what i’m responding to. trolling or not, i see a lot of twitter fights in this vein but i struggle to find good examples of what to do with them… what change could be made to make it better
i read a really interesting article on trolls last night that framed the topic of online harassment in a really helpful way for me: <http://time.com/4457110/internet-trolls/>

attachments.title: How Trolls Are Ruining the Internet
attachments.text: They&rsquo;re turning the web into a cesspool of aggression and violence. What watching them is doing to the rest of us may be even worse
attachments.fallback: TIME Link: How Trolls Are Ruining the Internet

text: Whether or not twitter is a good place for nuanced conversation (it's not) and regardless of whether the OP meant "I read" or "you should read" the fact is that his main point was still that either women aren't as ambitious as men or that Steve jobs/bill gates are the sole archetypes we should respond to - which is wrong headed regardless.

I think that makes a lot of sense, and it definitely helps frame the problem for me. 

I have a question: if this was a conversation within our own walls, had between our own team members, how would we address it? when i see it happening on twitter i think of firefights and escalation and public shaming. what’s the best way to deal with something like this internally?
That's sort of the core troll issue.
how so?
People went nuts when you couldn't be anonymous on YouTube anymore
The layer of abstraction either serves to help escalation accidentally or on purpose
Face to face almost always helps with understanding
that particular conversation didn’t seem too anonymous, though it was purely a digital exchange
the problem at this point is that  a troll and a misstep are indistinguishable online
interesting
and trolling is so common that its the default assumption just for self-presrvation
i can in no way fault a woman on the internet for assuming the worst
or in real life for that matter
yeah i’m with you on that
but the methods of de-escalation don't exist online in any tangible way
the baseline of that would be seeing a human being react

personally, i think problems like these are not dealt with or “solved” easily. i put solved in quotes because i don’t think it can be addressed and put to bed. people need to keep talking. and keep their responses and comments personal to their experiences and knowledge. but we should all be ok with the fact that many of these issues are going to stay unresolved not going to be put to rest in a single conversation (much less on twitter). keep asking questions <@U026E0ZNR>! they lead to good dialogue.
related service, local, <http://civilcomments.com>
whoa <@U06DFL7BP> you mean i *should* actually read the comments??
i’m not saying you SHOULD or SHOULDN’T but they are definitely of a higher quality when there’s >1 person contributing to community management on every message
for sure
comments are a gnarly nut to crack and i love that someone is taking a swing
Charles' Shirts Are a Lie.
ALWAYS LOG OFF
<@U06DFL7BP|charlesv> has left the channel
<@U06DFL7BP|charlesv> has joined the channel

yeah, thanks for engaging in these discussions, all. for me, what’s really important for this particular group is building a resource and base of education on how to handle good/bad instances of diversity and inclusion. most of us have been around this stuff long enough to just know what to do and how to respond but it's an assumption that everyone will know how to deal with problematic situations like this. i don’t think it’s too unreasonable to anticipate people on our team (now or in the future) that create issues out of ignorance rather than malice. i’d love to know how to guide that type of person in a healthy way to a better place of understanding if we ever get to that point

and to your point Sarah, it isn’t necessarily a thing to be figured out in a single conversation. but talking through this stuff and entertaining challenging questions really helps to strengthen the collective conscious
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zoLCw4Xg0uo>
(not to cite a movie where a white man helps samurais figure out how to samurai)
"i can in no way fault a woman on the internet for assuming the worst or in real life for that matter” - THANK YOU.
<@U026PHQ3J>

In my experiences with holding people accountable for their harm, though not in tech, what I’ve seen as most effective is several factors:
- a community understanding that everybody participates in destructive behavior, therefore it’s important to have empathy for people when they fuck up. Conversely, people who have institutional power (white, male, straight, and abled people) work to build personal empathy for people they harm.
- willingness of people in positions of power and/or influence to take responsibility to learn enough to teach people who listen to them
- a widely-understood and adopted structure of holding people accountable for their actions
that’s really good, thanks for that
